Morgan Stanley's house broker. And here they come.

11:14 am
BE

- The company's financial guidance for FY 2016/17 (which is 'new news' today) is significantly more cautious than we had anticipated. Gross Margins are now guided to be up 50-100 bps in Clothing & Home (we were previously modeling +150bps) and flat in Food (in line with our forecasts), whilst operating costs are guided to increase by 3.5% (we were previously modeling an increase of 3.4%). The big variance to our forecasts, however, comes at the top-line, where management is encouraging investors to expect "a similar sale trend to last year". This would seem to suggest LfLs of c -3% in Clothing & Home and around flat in Food (whereas we had been modelling +1% in Clothing & Home and +0.6% in Food).
- Adjusting for this new guidance we expect consensus Pre Tax Profit forecasts for FY 2016/17 to come down to around £620m-£630m (which would imply c31.5p of EPS). According to Bloomberg the consensus average is currently £712m, so we think most brokers are likely to cut forecasts by 10-15% over the next couple of days.

BE

- Although this may seem a dramatic reduction, we think it worth bearing in mind that the company made Pre Tax Profits of £623m in FY 2013/14, so one could argue that management, with its new strategic plan, is preparing to use the last two years of profit growth in order to put the business on a more sustainable footing. If the new plan works we think shareholders will look back and consider this a modest investment. We acknowledge, though, that, at this stage, this remains a big 'if'.

BE

Wait, no, stop.

11:15 am
BE

"one could argue that management, with its new strategic plan, is preparing to use the last two years of profit growth in order to put the business on a more sustainable footing" .....

BE

One could argue that.

BE

Or one could argue that M&S has been perpetually stuck in a strategic plan since the 1980s.

11:15 am
BE

Because that's just retail.

BE

You spend money doing up the shops. That never ends.

BE

You try to upgrade logistics, you fiddle about with leases, you attempt to patch up the broken bits of the website.

11:17 am
BE

And you tweak prices! You do this five times daily! Cutting the price of pants by 50p is not a strategic plan to put the business on a sustainable footing!

BE

Back to MOST.

BE

- We think shareholders should also take comfort from the fact that the ordinary dividend is not only being retained, but increased (from 18.0p in FY 2014/15 to 18.7p for FY 2015/16). We note net debt fell c£90m in FY 2015/16, despite the company paying both its ordinary dividend and returning £150m to shareholders via a share buy back. Indeed the company has announced today that it intends to return a further £75m to shareholders in H1 FY 2016/17 (though this time via a 4.6p special dividend, rather than via a buyback). We believe that the company's strong cash generation and increasing willingness to return that cash to shareholders should help support the shares in the coming weeks and months.

11:17 am
BE

- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, M&S is trading on 12.4x Calendar 2016 earnings, 6.7x EBITDA with a 4.5% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 14.7x, 8.6x and 3.1% dividend yield

BE

"Hello, we're a value trap, but here's some money to help you forget that."

BE

Great.

11:18 am
BE

Credit Suisse is nonplussed.

BE

■ We regard the business plan under new CEO Steve Rowe to be disappointing: The plan for GM is largely as expected with an emphasis on re-establishing the price position, reversing the upscaling of the price architecture and narrowing ranges. There is nothing on whether any changes are expected for the sub brands. In Food the only material change seems to be the addition of another 100 Simply Food stores pa over the next two years, which seems risky in an increasingly crowded market, where M&S's declining LFL is showing some signs of cannibalisation. On International and Property the company will update on its strategy in the Autumn. We had hoped the company would announce the closure of China and expand Food in Europe. We may get a directional steer at the meeting but the lack of urgency or any reflection of the need to make structural change to the UK portfolio is the most disappointing
■ There were few surprises in FY results: Clean PBT was £689.6m (CS £681m, cons £673m) with EPS of 35.0p (CS 34.7p), The FY dividend was 18.7p +3.9% Y/Y (final 11.9p) and Y/E net debt was £2.14bn (CS £2.3bn). GM gross margins +245bp, Food flat and UK opex +1.8% which were all exactly as had forecast. Intnl EBIT was £55.8m -40% Y/Y). The only surprise was a 4.5p special dividend for 1H.
■ Guidance looks tough: GM gross margin +50-100bp (CS +20bp), Food gross margin flat (CS -10bp) and Opex +3.5% (CS +2.4%) with another tough year for International, we had forecast a recovery to £86m. Our forecasts are c5% below consensus, and given tough market conditions we would anticipate that consensus will have to come down significantly. We do not believe that M&S can trade its way out of trouble, given the store estate, GM infrastructure and underlying market and until we see concrete signs that the company can rectify this we reiterate our Underperform rating.

BE

Think we flagged up the China closure rumours a week or so ago.

11:21 am

BE

PM

See Liberum are outright sellers

11:22 am
PM

Steve Rowe has been in place as CEO for two months but brings his 25 years front line M&S experience to the business of turning around the company and especially the clothing division. He has already streamlined the management structure reducing the executive board from six to four and halving the 20-strong operating committee.

Today's FY results bring a strategic review. Gross margin gains from better sourcing in clothing will at least in part be re-invested in price; the company will lower price points and pursue a less promotional strategy, although in truth this has been the case for some months now, we believe so is the evolution of an existing trend. The company targets a return to sales growth but there will be both gross margin cost from lowering price points and higher operating costs from increasing staff numbers and improving customer service. The focus on sales growth is sensible, and in fact inevitable after five years of declines but the volume gains that M&S can achieve in a competitive market may not be enough to offset margin pressures. The company itself says that: 'These actions, combined with the difficult trading conditions, will have an adverse effect on profit in the short term'

PM

The problems of a large, inflexible store base have been addressed, indeed this is not a short term problem to solve, but we feel must be addressed for substantive progress to be made. The company has to many stores and the large freehold and long leasehold base allows little flexibility. In addition, closing a large number of stores, which we believe that the company must do to make a real difference to profitability will be difficult politically and socially given the importance of a large M&S store as the retail cornerstone in many communities.

PM

Recovery has to be about clothing

The graph below show the decline of implied general merchandise sales per store, showing the extent to which the new CEO must find a way to grow sales and to make the space more productive. The channel shift to online, currently with a higher cost to serve, remains dilutive to margins.

In addition, we are proposing to close our UK defined benefit (DB) pension scheme for future service accrual (it has been closed to new members since 2002) and enrol current defined benefit members in our defined contribution savings plan from April 2017. We have started a period of consultation with our people on both of these proposals.

Cazenove to sum things up. They say "we're not surprised by any of this but our forecasts seem to be 15% too high."

11:27 am
BE

· No surprises in the strategic plan. The key points of the plan in General Merchandise are: 1) price investment in Clothing, focused on opening price point product; 2) investing in staff costs; and 3) some range rationalization and improvements to availability. None of this is unexpected. We think price investment is the right strategy for the long run health of the business (our most recent pricing work suggests that M&S is still c.20% higher than Next on average in OPP product), and indeed the investments that took place in Q4 on targeted lines did generate strong volume uplifts. However, M&S has spoken many times in the past of plans to rationalize the range and improve availability. Similarly investing in staff costs means adding incremental cost into the business ahead of any potential LFL uplifts which, at this stage of the strategy, we struggle to view positively.

BE

M&S will update on the UK store estate, International and organization in the Autumn. Given that retail occupancy costs represent over a third of opex we consider it disappointing that there is no update at this stage.
· FY17 guidance: first take is that forecasts move lower by 10-15%. Guidance is for a FY17 sales trend that is similar to FY16. In GM we assume this means a LFL closer to -3% than the +1% that we are currently forecasting. The GM gross margin is expected to increase by 50-100bps (including pressure of 70bps from FX). In Food a similar sales trend would imply broadly flat LFL sales and M&S has guided to a flat gross margin. UK opex is expected to rise +3.5%. Overall, as a first take, we estimate that this implies downgrades to FY17 consensus PBT forecasts in the region of 10-15%.

BE

There. That's more than enough M&S I feel.

11:32 am
PM

Helen Brand on luxury brands, fittingly

PM

I will give you the cover page and usual place the rest

PM

Retail has seen a slowdown in 2016 to date; Swatch next to report
Worldwide tourism spending via Global Blue fell -5% in Q1 and -14% in April.
Company commentary has also been cautious from Richemont (April -15% organically)
Swatch is next to report in July; we forecast flat organic growth for 2016. This looks
increasingly ambitious with the data suggesting at least a high single digit decline YTD.
This would mean more margin pressure. Every 1% lower top line is at least 3% off EPS.

11:33 am
PM

Price positioning is a key industry question; new products at the "entry" level
Prices within hard luxury are aligned globally which is a stark difference to the stretched
differentials in soft luxury. However, following significant price/ mix shifts over the last
few years there has been a gap at retail left at ~CHF 5,000 price point where there is
currently high demand. Our UBS Evidence Lab work shows that Cartier watches have
just 12% of SKU's below €7,500 currently. This has led to new product introductions
and key for the industry going forward will be the volume reaction here.

PM

Swiss watch export data for April -10% shows further caution from retailers
Retailers remain overstocked and Emperor announced on 31st March it still has 230
days of watches inventory as at Dec 2015 (unchanged versus Jun 2015). This ongoing
inventory pressure is reflected by latest April Swiss export data as wristwatches declined
-10% (-14% adjusted for one extra trading day). By region, Hong Kong remains soft at
-17%, Mainland China decelerated -36% with Europe -14% impacted by the events in
Paris/ Brussels. By price point, the luxury CHF3,000+ segment fell -13% but momentum
improved for the CHF 500-3,00 segment (+3.5%)

PM

How much of a risk is the Apple Watch?
The recent profit warning from Fossil suggests that the Apple Watch/ wearables are a
tangible threat at the entry price point. UBS Evidence Lab commissioned a proprietary
survey of 6,171 smartphone users across the US, UK, Germany, mainland China and
Japan in September/October 2015. The results indicated that the first generation of
Apple Watch still has further to run to be materially attractive. There may yet still be
further risk in our view that the second-generation Apple Watch can improve consumer
perceptions further and we see this as an overhang for Swatch through 2016.

11:33 am
PM

A subject of some interest to certain people on the commercial side, here at the FT

11:38 am
BE

There has been some recent, non-specific media speculation about a potential Rio Tinto acquisition of Freeport-McMoRan.

BE

By "recent, non-specific media speculation" I think they mean a downstory mention on the FT market report last week.

BE

We have heard this speculation
many times in the past, and we have typically dismissed it entirely for multiple
reasons. While our analysis indicates that a hypothetical Rio bid for Freeport
does have some strategic rationale, we conclude that a tie-up is still unlikely.
Even without a deal, RIO and FCX are two of our top picks.

11:39 am
BE

Why a Rio acquisition of Freeport would make sense: In this report, we discuss 10
reasons why Freeport would be a good acquisition target for Rio. By acquiring Freeport, Rio
would reduce its relative exposure to iron ore and increase its exposure to copper, extract
at least $400m per year of cost savings from the combined companies, and face limited risk
of a bidding war. We estimate that Rio could justify an all-share acquisition at up to $20
per FCX share. Freeport's balance sheet has improved this year and its geopolitical risk has
arguably been reduced following the sale of the Tenke Fungurume mine in the DRC. Rio's
incoming CEO, Jean-Sébastien Jacques, is head of the company's copper business and likely
has a mandate from the board to deliver some growth after Rio has gone through a multi-
year period of austerity. Making an acquisition now, at a weak point in the cycle, could be
a prudent move.
But there are clear hurdles that rule this out for now: While a Rio acquisition of
Freeport makes some sense from a strategic perspective, our analysis indicates that a deal is
unlikely for now. The main problem is geopolitical risk in Indonesia. We would not expect
Rio to even consider approaching Freeport until the ongoing Contract of Work discussions
regarding Grasberg are resolved. The timing and outcome of these negotiations is highly
uncertain. In addition, it is not clear that Freeport would be a willing seller at this time (any
deal would almost certainly have to be friendly), and Freeport may still have too much debt
to attract interest from Rio.
Rio is likely to start focusing on organic growth and bolt on acquisitions: BHP
Billiton has recently indicated that it has a renewed focus on growth. We expect Rio to
do the same when current CEO, Sam Walsh, is replaced by Mr. Jacques this July. Some
of Rio's growth will come from organic projects (the underground expansion at the Oyu
Tolgoi copper mine in Mongolia, the Amrun bauxite mine project in Australia, and the
Silvergrass iron ore project in Australia), but acquisitions of tier-1 assets in copper and other
commodities such as metallurgical coal will likely be considered as well. We would prefer
if Rio and BHP would use cash flow to continue to pay down debt as a top priority rather
than invest in growth, but growth investment is more likely at this point based on recent
comments from their management teams.
Freeport's focus is on debt reduction: Freeport's net debt has fallen from $20.2bn at
the start of this year to about $16bn now, pro-forma for asset sales announced so far in
2016. While the company's liquidity has improved as well, management has indicated that
further debt reduction is a priority. We expect additional asset sales at premium valuations
from Freeport in the near-term. These asset sales may reduce the company's exposure to a
longer-term recovery in the copper price, but they also ensure survival if things get worse.
Further deleveraging, and a successful outcome to negotiations in Indonesia, should be the
key company-specific drivers for the FCX share price.

BE

Sorry about the duff formatting.

BE

Christopher LaFemina is the analyst. One does wonder why, if Rio was going to buy anything, it didn't see the opportunity six months ago when everything was about 50% cheaper.

11:41 am
PM

BE

(@nichoman: What kind of premium would you want to offer for First Quantum, bearing in mind the equity's up and down by 50% most weeks?)

PM

Second tranche worth €10.3bn nearly agreed, of which €7.5bn in June
Eurozone finance ministers agreed overnight that Greece has met “most of the agreed prior actions” of its bailout, and subject to further verification “in the next few days” of their implementation, it endorsed a new ESM disbursement to Greece of €10.3bn. The first sub-tranche of €7.5bn will be released in June, and following sub-tranches will be contingent on other specific milestones (related to the privatisation agency, bank governance, energy sector). This represents a bigger disbursement than the €5.7bn originally envisaged, adds to the €21.4bn already lent by the ESM within the €86bn third bailout and to the €220bn of outstanding loans.
A plan on debt relief, but key decisions postponed until mid-2018
The Eurogroup agreed that debt relief, when and if agreed, should focus on capping Greece’s gross financing needs below 15% of GDP in the medium-term and 20% in the long-run. However, debt relief measures in the near term (ie before 2018) are limited – “smoothening of the EFSF repayment profile” and avoiding a 200bp step-up interest rate margin on €11.3bn of EFSF outstanding loans. Even the transfer of ANFA/SMP profits – which already occurred in 2013/14 – was delayed until 2018. Any other debt-alleviating actions “will be delivered at the end of the programme in mid-2018”, will be subject to political approval by the Eurogroup (against the IMF request) and will be subject to “full implementation of the programme”. The IMF remains on the sidelines for now, although it is due to assess its decision to participate in the programme “before the end of 2016”. Its envoy Poul Thomsen noted that the IMF had made 'an important concession' in the negotiations

11:41 am
PM

After six years of bailouts, debt sustainability remains highly uncertain
The disbursement of €10.3bn is certainly good news in the short term for Greece. It removes the risk of Greece defaulting on its debt redemptions to the IMF (€1.5bn) and the ECB (€2.3bn) before year-end. It provides resources for around half of built-up government arrears to be repaid, helping to loosen the still-very-tight domestic liquidity position and it probably allows the ECB to re-instate the waiver on Greek bonds collateral on 2 June, providing a cheaper source of funding for Greek banks. This should lead to some improvements in near-term economic prospects, although we reckon that the fiscal austerity recently approved represents a major headwind. Yet, the unwillingness of European creditors to take any firmer commitment on debt relief is negative news, although largely expected. It leaves Greece’s return to market funding uncertain and probably delays the inclusion of Greek bonds into the ECB’s QE until public debt is deemed sustainable by ECB/EU. Political uncertainty in Greece will likely persist, although the vague debt relief commitment could still provide some political capital to Greek PM Tsipras, who has been pledging a deal on debt relief since elected in Jan-15.

PM

Six years of bailouts

PM

That's some dedicated can-kicking

11:42 am
PM

The 2018 debt-alleviating measures fall well short of IMF recommendations –We note that the medium-term debt-reliving measures agreed overnight, and subject to the extensive list of criteria, are not detailed or particularly far-reaching. The Eurogroup statement even suggested they may not be required – “these measures will be implemented if an update of the debt sustainability analysis shows they are needed to meet the agreed gross financing needs benchmark”. They mainly encompass (i) the buy-out of some existing loans via ESM cheaper funding (presumably IMF loans, of which only some €10bn will be left by then) and (ii) “some targeted debt re-profiling” of only EFSF loans (€131bn) to “give comfort to the IMF and without incurring any additional costs for former programme countries or to the EFSF”. The IMF proposal to restore fiscal sustainability envisaged all existing official loans (only excluding IMF loans) to be deeply restructured, with maturities extended by up to 30 years, an explicit cap on interest rate at 1.5% and long grace periods to 2040.

PM

Avoids short-term crisis, but long-term issues unresolved – Eurozone creditors showed willingness to avoid a Greek crisis similar to that of summer 2015 but little desire to restore Greece’s fiscal and economic sustainability. They remain committed to making the Greek debt serviceable, if Greece sticks to the bailout programme. The IMF has caved on its requests for an upfront and meaningful debt relief commitment. The lack of debt relief commitment and the reaffirmation of overly-ambitious bailout targets (a primary fiscal surplus of 3.5% of GDP by 2018, from around 0% at present) suggest that restoring Greece’s medium-term fiscal sustainability is clearly not what is driving European creditors’ decisions at the moment. As German FinMin Schaeuble said on Tuesday, “we will take the decisions when they need to be made. Now I have the legitimacy and in 2018 it will be for those whom the German people have chosen in 2017".This, in our view, still leaves elevated risks that tensions could rise again between Greece and its creditors as soon as the latest injection of fresh official liquidity evaporates, possibly in early 2017

PM

11:48 am
BE

Here's Morgan Stanley's update post yesterday's briefing.

BE

1) Dividend resumption - key gating factors are W&G disposal and US
RMBS litigation: On Williams & Glyn, CEO McEwan cited a huge amount of
management time and manpower being expended, with 6,000 staff working
on the separation of the business. He noted the key difficulty is ensuring error
free transfer, given 2m customers to move, 700 systems to replicate and 190
products to offer and making sure the corporate internet banking service
'Bankline' can be recreated. As he has previously indicated, timing for
separation may slip past 31/12/2017 but he noted this is not certainly going to
happen. Resolving US RMBS litigation is still a work in progress with about 20
different pieces of litigation outstanding; the largest individual pieces are
viewed as likely DoJ and FHFA and there has been no substantial progress
there to update the market on.

BE

2) Intense focus on the cost base - with CIB, Ulster and Private Bank key
areas to improve: With a 76% adjusted cost:income ratio in 1Q16 (63% for
core franchises) RBS remain very focussed on improving efficiency and target
less than 50% over time. The CIB cost takeout is a lengthy process, but well on track,
with visibility in cutting the cost base 50% from £1.5bn in 2015 to c.£750m in
2019e. Management expects the Private Bank to be able to see costs come
down as last part of the international business is exited. Ulster has a new CEO
starting shortly who will be focussed on the cost base, but who will also look to
improve returns by growing loan balances in SME / mortgages where
opportunities arise and to reduce the capital allocation (UBIL had 29.6% CET1
ratio at Dec 2015).

11:49 am
BE

3) UK retail banking - still taking profitable share: RBS are taking share in
the UK mortgage market and grew balances well ahead of the market to
£108bn in 1Q16 (+13% y/y); they are not a price leader in the market and see
themselves as competing on service and certainty of execution while some
smaller players offer keener pricing / higher LTVs. Mortgage competition has
abated somewhat with margins ticking up to around 1.6% from 1.5% over the
last 6 months. RBS have also seen improved affluent customer retention rates
since the introduction of the NatWest Reward account (3% cashback on
household bills). Management believes the branch network is likely to shrink
further (after falling from 1600 to 1300 over the last couple of years), noting
the pace of this will be determined by customer needs and that there is no
target for branch numbers.

BE

4) RWA inflation an uncertainty - but expect pragmatism from UK
policymakers: RBS remain watchful and note there are a number of pieces of
regulation still to land (e.g. op risk, standardised floors etc); however, they are
reassured by the Bank of England stance that any new measures should not be
additive to capital requirements and that the UK system is reasonably
capitalised, and so remain comfortable with their 13% CET1 ratio guidance.

BE

BE

Investec's Gordon taking profit, as is his habit.

BE

Sections of the market are starting to anticipate a “Bremain-bounce” after 23 June. We think that such expectations have the potential to translate into a technical, short-term, reality. However, whereas (as policy) we remain silent on the merits of the Brexit debate, we do note that Chancellor Osborne expects a Bremain vote to underscore “lower for longer” interest rates and to support Sterling. Such a potential outcome would not help Barclays. In our coverage universe, we see Aldermore (Buy) as the only unequivocal winner.

11:51 am
BE

We downgrade Barclays to Hold (from Buy).This is, for us, a marginal call. Despite a 24% 7-week rally, (a period in which the FTSE100 index is up only 2%) trading on 0.7x 2015 tNAV or 0.6x 2016-18e tNAV, we do not see the stock as expensive. But equally, we think its near-term outlook for earnings and returns remains very challenging indeed. We expect the (already cut) 2016e dividend to remain uncovered for a 5th consecutive year, and we do not expect Barclays to achieve a double-digit RotE before 2019e (at the earliest).

Chancellor Osborne believes that a Brexit vote would trigger higher interest rates; so equally he anticipates that a Bremain vote should reinforce a lower-for-longer interest rate outlook. We expect such a scenario to place ongoing pressure on Barclays’ NIM. Indeed we broadly share CFO Tushar Morzaria’s views on the group’s muted revenue outlook (discussed on pages 2 & 3).

Chancellor Osborne believes that a Brexit vote would lead to a sharp decline in the £$ exchange rate, and so a Bremain vote may support a £$ recovery. Investec Economics forecasts that (based on the assumption of a Bremain vote) £/$ will rally to 1.48 in Q2 2016e and 1.53 in Q4 2016e. With more than 50% of Barclays’ IB revenues denominated in dollars, this would be another headwind.
